question: Why is it a good idea to trim the data?

answers.feedback: Try again. Trimming is typically recommended for ChIP-seq, CUT&RUN, and CUT&Tag.

answers.answer: Removing N's can improve alignment to our reference genome.
answers.feedback: Yes. Low quality bases can be trimmed at this step to improve our confidence of assigning the read to the correct genomic coordinate.
Yes. Adapter sequences should be absent, but, depending on the library preparation strategy, you may see these appear. Hint: They also might appear more often for CUT&RUN and CUT&Tag data.

answers.answer: Alignment of CUT&RUN and CUT&Tag may especially be impacted because they are more likely to have adapter sequences depending on the length of reads.
answers.feedback: Because CUT&RUN and CUT&Tag represent a finer fragmentation, if you choose longer sequencing (100-150 bp), there is a higher chance that we may sequence into the adapter on the opposite end of the fragment. That's no big deal, but we should trim these off.
